awd_titl_txt: Formation and evolution of upper oceanic crust from seismic data acquired over mature oceanic crust near the Sumatra and Alaska subduction zones
awd_abstract_narration:
The upper oceanic crust and its physical properties are well known near the mid-ocean ridge axis where the crust is formed. However, little is known about how the properties of the upper oceanic crust change as the crust ages, primarily because of the lack of the appropriate datasets over older crust. An important question that remains unanswered is whether or not hydrothermal circulation continues as the crust spreads away from the ridge axis. Heat flow measurements suggest that hydrothermal circulation persists, but it has been impossible to clarify from existing datasets the effects and the controls on this late stage circulation. This project will use recently collected marine seismic data over mature oceanic crust (>50 Myr) offshore the Sumatra and Alaska subduction zones to address these problems. These two datasets are very high quality and unique in that they allow imaging of the upper part of the oceanic crust. Understanding hydrothermal circulation in older crust is important because we do not know the extent of the chemical exchanges that occur between the earth and oceans in these vast regions that represent about 70% of the surface of the earth. The study supports the training of a Ph.D. graduate student. The project also involves an international collaboration with French colleagues.

This project will examine 2-D marine seismic data acquired over mature oceanic crust (>50 Myr) offshore the Sumatra and Alaska subduction zones.  These data were acquired in 2011 on the R/V Marcus Langseth and in 2009 on the M/V Geowave Champion during the TIDES Program (IPG-Paris).  The main objective of this study is to provide new insights on the seismic heterogeneity of the uppermost crust and the dominant processes that control the aging of upper oceanic crust. The long-streamer MCS data will provide seismic imaging of the upper crust including post-critical reflections seen at large offsets. The MCS imaging will also allow the characterization of variations in the sediment thickness, topography of the upper crust, and abundance of faulting within the sediments and upper crust.  The downward continuation followed by travel time modeling of the streamer data will provide the thickness and P-wave velocity of the two layers that constitute the upper crust.  Synthetic computation will generate further information on S-wave velocities and attenuation. Together the two datasets will allow the comparison between sections of oceanic crust formed at different spreading rates and of slightly different ages.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Downgoing oceanic plates are conveyor belts transporting water into subduction zone systems. Seawater stored in the incoming oceanic plate is first introduced during crustal formation and evolution and again, eventually, near the trench axis of subduction zones where plate bending occurs. Once subducted, water is thought to exert a first-order control on a wide range of subduction zone processes including arc magmatism and/or megathrust slip behavior. Although numerous previous refraction studies based on ocean bottom seismometer data provide constraints on the amount of water stored in the lower crust and uppermost mantle near subduction zones, there is a clear lack of information about how much water is present in the upper 1-2 km of oceanic crust in and outside plate bending areas. Our study focuses on the incoming oceanic plate outboard of two subduction zone segments: The Shumagin segment offshore the Alaska Peninsula and the Enggano Island segment offshore Sumatra that share similar characteristics (e.g. age, rates at which crust was accreted). Comparing the structure and properties of upper incoming plate in both segments allow us to extract and discuss factors that are most important in controlling the hydration state of upper oceanic crust and its along-strike variability. In this project, we used long offset marine multichannel seismic data to map out variations in the structure of mature upper oceanic crust such as sediment thickness and basement roughness. We also employed downward continuation of the wavefields followed by travel time streamer tomography to derive high-resolution P-wave velocity models for the upper crust. We then estimate porosity using differential effective medium theory to provide constraints on the hydration state of upper oceanic crust. Lastly, we discussed variations in the amount of seawater in the upper crust to variations in megathrust behavior and earthquake rupture history to obtain a better understanding of how the former might influence the latter.

Our study provides one of the first robust estimates of the amount of pore water present in the upper crust outboard of two subduction zones.  Although a similar amount of water is found in the uppermost extrusive layers (layer 2A) at both locations, it appears that the mechanisms controlling the hydration state of uppermost crusts are different. Outboard the Alaska trench, we found that normal faults due to plate bending increase the amount of pore water stored in the upper crust by 37%. Seismic data also reveal along strike variations in the abundance, style and direction of bending faults outboard of the Shumagin segment with increasing fault throws towards the west that we attribute to an increase of slab dip in that direction. In addition to a favorably oriented pre-existing fabric, our study thus indicates that change is slab dip is another important factor impacting bending faulting.  Outboard of the Sumatra trench, the curvature of the downgoing plate is much less pronounced, and very few bending faults are observed compared to Alaska. We suggest the relatively low P-wave seismic velocities in the uppermost crust (Layer 2A) arises from the combination of the slow, ongoing deformation of the Indo-Australian plate and the reopening of small shallow cracks due to the gentle plate bending in the thinly sedimented outer-rise region and subsequent infiltration of seawater into these cracks. We found that the diffuse deformation of the Indo-Australian plate not only affects the uppermost crust but also the sheeted dike complex underneath. In the sheeted dikes complex, we image several 5-10km wide zones of low P-wave velocities and high Poisson?s ratios that suggest pervasive fracturing and higher water content. Outside the bending area, our P-wave velocity averages at the top of the fast spread crust offshore Alaska compare relatively well with recent averages for the slow to intermediate spread crusts in the Atlantic. We attribute some of the variations to differences in basement roughness, sedimentation rates and basement burial depth between the two ocean basins.


Last Modified: 04/12/2022
Modified by: Anne Becel
